channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump’s Special Master Request Left Him Open to Justice Dept. Strike
item.description: A legal back-and-forth produced a straightforward narrative of how Mr. Trump and his lawyers repeatedly dodged the government’s attempts to recover sensitive documents for more than a year.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department used a routine court filing to disclose new evidence that former President Donald J. Trump and his legal team may have interfered with the inquiry.

item.title: Trump’s Lawyers Renew Push for Special Master in Documents Inquiry
item.description: A filing claimed that the Justice Department was criminalizing the former president’s possession of “his own presidential records,” a stance at odds with the Presidential Records Act.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of former President Donald J. Trump outside the Federal District Court in West Palm Beach, Fla., where a hearing is scheduled for Thursday.

item.title: How the Photo of Top Secret Folders at Trump’s Home Came About
item.description: Federal agents arrayed classified materials on a floor at former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida residence for a photograph as a standard part of their evidence-gathering procedures.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: In its court filing, the Justice Department included a photograph of documents seized from Mar-a-Lago.

item.title: Trump Lawyers May Become Witnesses or Targets in Documents Case
item.description: Two lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump are under increased scrutiny after new details emerged about a failure to fully comply with a subpoena for documents marked as classified.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Christina Bobb, one of former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers, signed a statement attesting that all the sensitive material he took had been returned.

item.title: The Pandemic Erased Two Decades of Progress in Math and Reading
item.description: The results of a national test showed just how devastating the last two years have been for 9-year-old schoolchildren, especially the most vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:description: The declines in the national test scores spanned almost all races and income levels and were markedly worse for the lowest-performing students.

item.title: Pencil, chalk and first-aid kits: Ukrainian children return to school in the midst of war.
item.description: An estimated 2.8 million of the nation’s 6 million children have been forced from their homes because of the war. If they are fortunate enough to find a seat in a classroom, it will likely be in an unfamiliar town or city.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: School No. 3, like many buildings in Bucha, was damaged during the Russian occupation in March but it is currently undergoing repairs so that students can return to in-person classes soon.

item.title: Serena Williams’s Magical Run at the US Open Isn’t Over Yet
item.description: If two nights earlier was about posterity and sweet send-offs, Round 2 was about doing everything possible to win a tennis match, as Williams beat the world No. 2, Anett Kontaveit, in three sets.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

item.title: It Was Anett Kontaveit Against Serena Williams, and the Crowd
item.description: Kontaveit was up for the challenge of facing Williams in front of fans who had little interest in her winning as they celebrate Williams’s career. She forced a third set, but the fans got what they wanted.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Anett Kontaveit rebounded after losing a first-set tiebreaker but could not recover enough to win the match.

item.title: Coco Gauff Warms Up the Court for Serena Williams, and Gets a Win
item.description: The 18-year-old American beat Elena-Gabriela Ruse of Romania, 6-2, 7-6 (4), to advance to the third round at the U.S. Open.
item.dc:creator: Kris Rhim
item.media:description: Coco Gauff will play Madison Keys, another American, in the third round.

item.title: Mary Peltola, a Democrat, Defeats Sarah Palin in Alaska’s Special House Election
item.description: Ms. Peltola notched a major upset against Ms. Palin and will finish the remaining four months of the term of Representative Don Young, who died in March.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Ash Adams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mary Peltola’s victory in Alaska adds to a series of recent wins for Democrats.

item.title: Biden’s Message Shifts From Compromise to Combat Ahead of Midterms
item.description: President Biden is spending less time hailing the virtues of unity and more time calling out Republicans and dangers to democracy.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden is hoping that his party can maintain control of Congress and deliver a forceful rebuke to former President Donald J. Trump and his followers.

item.title: Michigan Board Says Abortion Referendum Should Not Go to Voters
item.description: Abortion rights supporters gathered more than 750,000 signatures, but the petitions they circulated had formatting problems.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:description: An abortion rights demonstrator in Detroit after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June.

item.title: Republicans Downplay Trump and Abortion on Their Sites Before Midterms
item.description: At least 10 Republican candidates in competitive races have updated their websites to minimize their ties to the former president or to adjust their stances on abortion.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adam Laxalt is running against Senator Catherine Cortez Masto in a Nevada race that Republicans see as one of their best chances to pick up a Senate seat.

item.title: China May Have Committed ‘Crimes Against Humanity’ in Xinjiang, U.N. Says
item.description: The organization’s human rights office delivered its much-delayed report minutes before Michelle Bachelet, the U.N. high commissioner for human rights, was to leave office.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce and Austin Ramzy
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A security guard at a detention center in Yarkant County, Xinjiang, China, last year. Delays to the U.N. report about abuses in the region prompted fierce pushback from rights groups.

item.title: F.D.A. Authorizes Updated Covid Booster Shots Targeting Omicron Subvariants
item.description: The agency cleared two options aimed at subvariants that are now dominant, hoping to curtail a fall or winter surge.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:description: Vaccinations remain the cornerstone of the government’s coronavirus strategy, even with tests and treatments widely available.

item.title: How the Pandemic Shortened Life Expectancy in Indigenous Communities
item.description: New federal data outline the scale of suffering among Native Americans and Alaska Natives.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Roni Caryn Rabin and Mark Walker
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Gathering for the funerals of Severiano Buck and Bace Wallace, brothers who died from Covid complications, at their family plot on the Navajo Nation in New Mexico last year.

item.title: How an Afghan Soccer Player Escaped the Taliban and Began a New Life
item.description: How an Afghan soccer player and her teammates fled their homes, outran a murderous regime and forged the uncertain beginnings of a new life.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur

item.title: Could the Courts Block Biden’s Student Loan Relief Plan?
item.description: Just last year, President Biden himself cast doubt on whether he had the authority to cancel student loan debt on such a broad basis.
item.dc:creator: Spencer Bokat-Lindell
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by Pool, Paul Taylor and Drew Angerer, via Getty Images

item.title: ‘Defund the Police’ Is Dead. Now What?
item.description: Have we simply become inured to police shootings? Do these lives no longer matter?
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:description: Protesters in Richmond, Va., in 2020.

item.title: The Anti-Abortion Movement Is Gunning for Fetal Personhood
item.description: Despite clear political headwinds, the movement has embraced a push for fetal personhood.
item.dc:creator: Mary Ziegler
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)

item.title: Ashley Judd: The Right to Keep Private Pain Private
item.description: I could not help my mother, Naomi Judd, who lost a long battle against mental illness. I can, however, do something about how she is remembered.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Judd

item.title: Gov. Jay Inslee Is Taking a Well-Earned Climate Victory Lap
item.description: “I didn’t end up in the White House, but I do believe that my policies have, which is a thrill.”
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells

item.title: Mikhail Gorbachev’s True Legacy
item.description: He was a rock star for a nation at rock bottom.
item.dc:creator: Serge Schmemann

item.title: With ‘House of the Dragon’ and ‘The Rings of Power,’ We’ve Entered the Age of Blockbuster TV
item.description: To truly rule the television world, the two fantasy series need to borrow from one another’s strengths.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

item.title: What the Champions League Is Lacking
item.description: Europe’s richest competition offers the best of what soccer can deliver. But the World Cup still has something it can’t match.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Real Madrid, last year’s champion, and Manchester City are back where both feel they belong.

item.title: John Lithgow on an Actor’s Education
item.description: The Emmy Award-winning star of TV, stage and movies discusses his memoir, “Drama.” And the British writer Maggie O’Farrell talks about her novel “Hamnet.”
item.media:credit: Photo illustration: The New York Times; Photos: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times; David Levenson/Getty Images

item.title: At One of Canada’s Top Destinations, Tourists Are Back but Much Has Changed
item.description: The towns in and around Banff National Park are teeming again, but overseas visitors are scarce, as are hotel and restaurant workers.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Most of the tourists flocking to Banff National Park this summer are Canadians.

item.title: Summer’s Last Gasp Has Arrived
item.description: Our last newsletter edition of the season focuses on summer missions accomplished and those still on the to-do list.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: As the sun slowly sets on summer, it’s not too late to finish off those activities still on your checklist.

item.title: U.K. Prime Minister Race Ends With Little Focus on Economy
item.description: The contest to succeed Boris Johnson as Conservative Party leader and prime minister has often seemed divorced from Britain’s fast-growing problems.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Liz Truss, the foreign secretary and front-runner to replace Boris Johnson as prime minister, at Wembley Arena in London on Wednesday.

item.title: The West’s Illusions About Gorbachev and the Victory of Liberalism
item.description: As the Soviet Union’s final leader, Mikhail Gorbachev dreamed of a “common European home,” but three decades later that tantalizing idea remains out of reach.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Mikhail Gorbachev, when he led the Soviet Union, addressing the U.N. General Assembly in December 1988.

item.title: Reported Sexual Assaults in Military Rose 13% in 2021, Officials Say
item.description: The easing of coronavirus restrictions may have contributed to the increase.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Defense Department has long struggled with sexual assaults and a reporting structure that had required reports to be filed through the military’s chain of command.

item.title: Charlbi Dean, Star of ‘Triangle of Sadness,’ Dies at 32
item.description: A South African-born actress and model, she had a breakout role in the satirical “Triangle of Sadness,” due in theaters in the fall.
item.dc:creator: Reggie Ugwu
item.media:description: The model and actress Charlbi Dean, who starred in the film “Triangle of Sadness” and was a regular on the CW superhero series “Black Lightning.”

item.title: Does CBD Help With Insomnia?
item.description: The research is sparse, experts say, but there are some hints about how it could soothe you to sleep.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: How to Stop Snoring: Solutions and Remedies
item.description: This sleep-disrupting problem can be caused by a variety of things, but experts say there are ways to find relief.
item.dc:creator: Erik Vance
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What’s the Best Nondairy Milk Alternative?
item.description: Soy milk, nut milks and other products may offer unique benefits.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Why Do I Feel Sick Before My Period?
item.description: Researchers don’t fully understand the menstrual cycle’s effects on the immune system, but experts say there are reasons some may feel sick at certain points.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Preventative’ Botox: Do Injections Work to Reduce Wrinkles?
item.description: Or are injections just a temporary, addictive fix?
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Katie Gregson-MacLeod Sang About a ‘Complex’ Love. TikTok Responded.
item.description: The 21-year-old Scottish folk singer-songwriter found a sudden hit by tapping into the platform’s appetite for melancholy with a striking, sorrowful chorus.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Jaime Molina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gregson-MacLeod began posting to TikTok in 2020, a few months into the pandemic, and had been studying at college and working in a coffee shop when her song took off.
